channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: A Cooling in Poland’s Love Affair With the U.S.
item.description: When President Obama visits Poland on Tuesday, he will find a nation still heavily pro-American, but where the focus has turned to the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China’s Solar Panel Production Comes at a Dirty Cost
item.description: A solar panel made in China would have to be in service as much as 30 percent longer than a European model to compensate for the extra energy used in its production, an American study found.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Anger in China After McDonald’s Patron Beaten to Death
item.description: Six people from a group known as the Church of the Almighty God were arrested in the killing of a woman at a McDonald’s restaurant in eastern china, but a cellphone video of the attack raised questions about whether witnesses should have intervened.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: 25 Years Later, Details Emerge of Army’s Chaos Before Tiananmen Square
item.description: Interviews with former Communist party officials and army documents show how a general’s defiance triggered tremors before a bloody crackdown.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS and CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: A photo of a man defying a line of tanks near Tiananmen Square is famous worldwide, but stringently suppressed in China.

item.title: With New Palestinian Government Come Many Questions, and Some Answers
item.description: What is in it for Hamas? What might Israel do? Jodi Rudoren, the Jerusalem bureau chief of The New York Times, provides some answers.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority, right, gives Prime Minister Rami Hamdallah a letter last week in Ramallah, in the West Bank, authorizing a consensus government be formed.

item.title: With Ukraine Crisis Cooling, Obama Sets Off to Soothe European Friends
item.description: The United States is boasting it rallied allies on the Continent to contain the Eastern European crisis, but many remain wary of what Putin may have in mind to do next.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: President Obama at the presidential palace in Warsaw in May 2011. On Monday, he begins a trip to Poland, Belgium and France.

item.title: Planned Celebration for Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl Just Got a Whole Lot Bigger
item.description: News that the U.S. soldier was finally free made it a far more momentous weekend than anyone could have imagined in Hailey, Idaho, his hometown.
item.dc:creator: By MATT FURBER
item.media:credit: Bill Schaefer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Signs in support of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl at Zaney’s River Street Coffee House in Hailey, Idaho, where he used to work.

item.title: Prisoner Trade Yields Rare View Into the Taliban
item.description: Representatives of both sides played down the idea that the exchange, long seen as a crucial prelude to any broader talks, might breathe new life into a peace effort.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Etihad Nears Deal for a Stake in Alitalia
item.description: Etihad, owned by the government of Abu Dhabi, plans to make an offer for a stake of up to 49 percent of the money-losing Italian airline.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK

item.title: Mentally, G.I. Has Long Path Back to Idaho
item.description: Military officials said that the recovery of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl would be a multistep process, beginning with treatment in Germany before further care in the United States.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:credit: Kyle Green/The Idaho Statesman, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In Hailey, Idaho, Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl’s hometown, Diane Walker took a picture of a sign celebrating his release by the Taliban.

item.title: Krasnyy Luch Journal: At Ukraine’s Perilous Border, Law Is Dispensed by Men in Masks
item.description: Ukraine’s easternmost province of Luhansk has become a lawless expanse where dying coal mines and joblessness feed an insurgency.
item.dc:creator: By SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: A pro-Russian activist inspected a car last month at a checkpoint outside the village of Schastya, about 15 miles from the eastern Ukrainian city of Luhansk.

item.title: DealBook: Mexico Authorizes Arrests in Fraud at Citigroup Unit
item.description: Mexican authorities declined to say how many or which former executives of the Citigroup subsidiary Banamex were being sought.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN and MICHAEL CORKERY
item.media:description: An advertisement for Banamex in Mexico City.

item.title: Scots Are Divided Over Independence, and Its Economic Costs
item.description: Voices inside and outside Scotland warn of the implications of independence, even as its supporters say Scotland would be better off by itself.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:description: Members of a pro-independence organization in Glasgow.

item.title: In GPS Battle, Russia Sets Restrictions of Its Own
item.description: In imposing restrictions on the American satellite navigation system, Russia is answering the refusal of the United States to allow similar base stations on its soil.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Israel Warns Against Embracing Newly Reconciled Palestinian Government
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel called on the international community “not to run to recognize” the new Palestinian government scheduled to be sworn in Monday, saying it rests on a terrorist organization.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, second from right, said the Palestinian alliance would strengthen terrorism.

item.title: Killings in Iraq, at 799, Reach a Monthly High
item.description: The Islamic State of Iraq and Syria has intensified its attacks across Iraq as political rivals work to form a new government.
item.category: Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Iraqi security forces at the scene of the killing of a member of the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria on Saturday in Ramadi.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Sisi and the Palestinians
item.description: In the past, a strong and stable Egypt has meant more support for Palestine in the region and abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ALI JARBAWI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Rise and Fall of the Goddess of Democracy
item.description: A 33-foot-high statue became a mute yet powerful actor in the final drama on Tiananmen Square in 1989, reinvigorating the student protests and infuriating Communist Party leaders.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: The Goddess of Democracy was assembled on Tiananmen Square over two nights beginning May 29.

item.title: Primavera Sound Sets the Stage for Music Festivals Worldwide
item.description: Primavera Sound in Barcelona is an expansive music showcase that has gradually become one of the top tickets of the European festival season and a template for other promoters worldwide.
item.dc:creator: By MELENA RYZIK

item.title: Suspect Held in Jewish Museum Killings
item.description: The suspect, a 29-year-old Frenchman with a long criminal history, had traveled to Syria last year to join with radical Islamist fighters there, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: Mehdi Nemmouche was arrested in connection with last week’s fatal shooting at the Jewish Museum in Brussels.

item.title: Administration Defends Swap With Taliban to Free U.S. Soldier
item.description: The White House pushed back against Republican criticism that the deal was a dangerous transgression of longstanding policy against negotiating with terror groups, and might have violated American law.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN KNOWLTON
item.media:description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in a video released in 2010. Sergeant Bergdahl was freed on Saturday in a prisoner swap with the Taliban.

item.title: President of Georgian Abkhazia Resigns Under Pressure
item.description: President Aleksandr Z. Ankvab, whose popularity had plummeted amid deteriorating economic conditions, stepped down as the leader of Abkhazia, a breakaway region of Georgia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: The president of Abkhazia, Aleksandr Z. Ankvab, had survived several assassination attempts.

item.title: Three Kidnapped Missionaries Are Freed in Cameroon
item.description: The two Italian priests and a Canadian nun were held for nearly two months near Cameroon’s border with Nigeria in a region rife with Boko Haram militants.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Hagel Celebrates U.S. Soldier’s Release With a Surprise Afghan Visit
item.description: For Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel, the release of the American prisoner of war is the high point of his tenure in the cabinet so far.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Pablo Martinez Monsivais
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, right, with James Cunningham, the American ambassador to Afghanistan, arrived at Bagram Air Base on Sunday.

item.title: Bowe Bergdahl, American Soldier, Freed by Taliban in Prisoner Trade
item.description: Sergeant Bergdahl, the lone American prisoner of war from the Afghan conflict, has been released in exchange for five Taliban prisoners at Guantánamo Bay.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT and CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl in a video released in 2010. Sergeant Bergdahl was freed on Saturday in a prisoner swap with the Taliban.
